title: Graph of Polar Function - Average Rates of Changes

content.description:
This is a polar curve with one loop that has an indentation at radius 1 on the polar axis, to the left of the origin. The point is labeled C. The curve extends to the right.

The curve moves from point C, upward and to the right, passing through radii 2 and 3, to a maximum distance from the polar axis. The point is labeled B and is on radius 4.

From point B, the curve moves down and to the right, beyond radius 4, until it reaches radius 5 on the polar axis. The point is labeled A.

The curve has symmetry over the polar axis.

The maximum distance on the curve below the polar axis is labeled D.

In the polar coordinate system, the graph of a polar function <math alttext="r equals f open parentheses theta close parentheses"><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>θ</mi></mfenced></math> is shown with a domain of all real values of <math alttext="theta"><mi>θ</mi></math> for <math alttext="0 less or equal than theta less than 2 pi"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. On this interval of <math alttext="theta"><mi>θ</mi></math>, the graph has no holes, passes through each point exactly one time, and as <math alttext="theta"> <mi>θ</mi> </math> increases, the graph passes through the labeled points <math alttext="A"><mi>A</mi></math>, <math alttext="B"><mi>B</mi></math>, <math alttext="C"><mi>C</mi></math>, and <math alttext="D"> <mi>D</mi> </math>, in that order.
content.question: On which of the following intervals is the average rate of change of <math alttext="r"> <mi>r</mi> </math> with respect to <math alttext="theta"><mi>θ</mi></math> greatest?
